theText: Right! In any event, those car parking matters often tum into nice3008 MAIN COMMITTEE Tuesday, 25 March 1997 I regret to say that I feel that that has happened a lot. Largely we see in the protest movement, or what is left of it, somewhat of a Trotskyist rump. I am not saying necessarily that that is a bad thing, either. I do not think it is a bad thing, but the fact is that it is so marginalised that nobody bothers with it anyway, whereas the university protest movement of the old days was a much broader church. It is worthy of note that many of the people on both sides of politics were part of that protest movement, in one form or another, and have variously segregated to particular areas of politics; but frequently they joined for part of those protest movements, which was a good thing, and I think it spawned the sort of leadership potential that we see in the political sphere now. Are we going to lose that, if we do not remember that that is the way that university life is conducted? PerhapsI am lamenting the good old days. Are they gone for good-or bad, depending on one's point of view? In any event, the University of Canberra began life as the Canberra College of Advanced Education, and it was assisted through the transition to university by sponsorship from Monash University, and that process began in 1989. The sponsorship arrangements gave Monash University powers of approval over the development of the University of Canberra's graduate programs and over staff appointments at certain levels. In 1992 the vice-chancellors of both universities agreed that the continuation of sponsorship was unnecessary and it was time to bring the Big Brother type of relationship to an end. The bill makes appropriate and necessary amendments to the University of Canberra Act, to reflect the fact that the sponsorship arrangements no longer apply. Monash University is an institution of considerable significance for the government. The Treasurer ( Mr Costello) graduated from that university with a BA and a LLB (Hons). After completing his undergraduate studies, he went on to become a tutor in the faculties of law, economics and politics at Monash and was an academic of some renown who, in undergraduate life, was quite intensely involved in the campus scene. To return to my original point, for many years the university campus has been the breeding ground for leaders of the future, but the leaders were also found outside the university. It was a nice combination. We think of people like Ben Chifley in that regard, and you see on our side of politics a lot of people who have never been near a university but who have acquired the wisdom from the university of life. While it is still the case today that we are looking for potential leaders from the university culture, I wonder if the emphasis upon academic attainment is so ingrained in university life that it is at the expense of the joie de vivre exhibited by university students in the 1960s and 1970s. I wi111eave that with the Committee. The bill also introduces amendments to the Remuneration Tribunal Act to give effect to the policy that it is appropriate for higher education institutions in the states and territories to determine for themselves what role, if any, that tribunal should have in relation to determining salaries in those areas. It is worthy to observe also, in this fairly general debate, that one of the most often lamented or criticised matters when I was an undergraduate was the standard of performance of some of the academics. We now have a culture of the business orientated university, which highlights that in my time at university, in the 1970s, there was certainly a need to look at the standard of academics. They seemed frequently to be ungovernable by any standards of performance, output and ability to lecture. The students would complain constantly about performance, yet nothing was ever done. I hope that universities, particularly as a result of this measure, Tuesday, 25 March 1997 MAIN COMMITTEE 3009 recognise that there is a need to ensure standards of academic excellence and that the old catch cry of the independence of academics and their position in the debate is not used as a means of stifling justifiable criticism of some of the performance of academics. One lecturer that I had would not qualify to make tea in the office of a suburban solicitor, yet he was lecturing in a very significant area of law at the University of Queensland-having been passed on from a Melbourne university, with glowing references. It is those sorts of things I am talking about. I know I am going back some years, but I suspect that it is an area that universities should be looking at. Overall, I thank the Committee for this opportunity to participate in this debate and support the amendments. Amendment Bill and, as the member for Canberra, to speak principally about the transfer of the University of Canberra to the ACT government. I will talk in detail, in the brief time available, about some aspects to do with the university, but I want firstly to contrast the positive recognition in this bill of the self-government of the ACT, and the rights and capacity of the ACT to discharge this sort of obligation equally with the states, with the dreadful decision that parliament made last night with regard to the Andrews bill, the Euthanasia Laws Bill 1996. My principal concern about that bill was not its reflection on the rights of territories, as I made clear in my speech in the Main Committee. My concern was one of the substance of the matter. But we now have a situation where citizens of the three territories-if you include Norfolk Island, which is also part of my electorate-suffer a disease not known to any other Australian, called Andrews agony. They are the only people who have had this parliament impose upon them suffering which they desire to be freed from and from which the parliament which they had elected gave them an outlet. I deplore and regret that decision, and I choose very briefly to make that contrast with the very positive recognition for the ACT reflected in this legislation. I want only to speak about that part of the bill that relates to the University of Canberra. It is a transfer that was originally proposed by the university, and I think correctly. It was supported by the previous government and it was supported by this government, and reintroduced by it. It had been introduced by the previous government but not finished before the election. It is supported also by the Labor and Liberal parties in the ACT. It is, <;learly, not a politically controversial matter, nor institutionally, in terms of the views of the University of Canberra or any of the other principal education institutions of the ACT. The University of Canberra is a very important institution in ACT society and in the ACT economy. It sees itself as a significant part of the community. It participates actively within the community and makes a substantial contribution to it. I welcome, and was very interested in, some of the remarks made by the member for Dickson( Mr Tony Smith)-and I do not pretend that I shared them all-and I thought he was raising some interesting questions about the nature of universities and their relationship to their staff and students in this time of greater focus on the commercial role of universities. I was interested in his perception of the changing role of students in our society, as evidenced by his comment upon the lack of demonstrations-which was an interesting comment to hear from a member of the government-and his concern that the universities were becoming too business oriented and were changing their focus from the more academic and research orientation to a more commercial orientation. theText: I arise also to support the Education Legislation3010 MAIN COMMITTEE Tuesday, 25 March 1997 remarks from a government member and I welcome the fact that he raised those issues. As I say, I do not share all the views he expressed, but I thought they were interesting. If we want to look at why the volume and nature of public policy involvement by students change, we need to look at more than what is going on in universities; we need to have a look at what is going on much more broadly in the economy and in society. That would be a debate worth having, but it would be a different debate. One of the things that the University of Canberra does significantly here in the ACT relates to that commercial role in terms of the influx of foreign fee-paying students. They are important to the university. In the last year for which I have figures, foreign fee-paying students were 9.7 per cent of the university's total student load and contributed $5.41 million in 1995 to the university. They also contribute substantially to the broader economy of the ACT in terms of that $5.41 million and in terms of the other activities of those students while they are here participating at the university, and in terms of people who come to visit the ACT as a result of those students being here. Like all universities, the University of Canberra is facing financial difficulties as a result of the government funding changes. It is putting the university under pressure. It is requiring decisions to be made that the administration, the students and the staff do not welcome. I hope that we can see some easing of that relentless pressure upon tertiary institutions in general and, for the purpose of this debate, the University of Canberra in particular, in the forthcoming budget. The University of Canberra makes a substantial broader regional contribution. It says in its mission statement and objectives that the university sets itself to be the principal knowledge resource for the ACT and its hinterland and to possess the strongest possible links between the university and the community. It is very significant in the ACT. It is important that it raises that broader question of its significance in the region. One of the causes of concern to me, when people assess the economy of the ACT, is the failure of people to understand the complex and important interrelationship between that economy and the economy of the whole of the south-east of New South Wales, most obviously with Queanbeyan but quite importantly with the much broader south-eastern New South Wales region of which Canberra operates as the major regional city. It is also a university of national significance. I cannot do justice to that in the time available, but I have been aware of, and in some ways rather involved in, the important work it does at the Australian Centre for Local Government Studies, with the CRCs, with the National Centre for Social and Economic Modelling and with the Ngunnawal Centre for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander education. So you can see broader national involvement and contribution by the University of Canberra, and that reinforces the extent to which I welcome its role here and this legislation transferring responsibility to the ACT government. The final point I want to make, because I did promise those seeking to organise the agenda that I would finish in 10 minutes, is about the underestimated contribution of universities in regional cities-not just Canberra, but also in most of Australia's major regional cities-in 'I e employment area. Directly, with academic staff and non-academic staff, plus measuring the full-time equivalents of the casual staff in the various categories, there are a thousand jobs at the University of Canberra. Very many other jobs are indirectly contributed to by its existence. The whole high technology park across the road from the university would not exist and thrive in the way it does without its interrelationship with the IT and engineering schools Tuesday, 25 March 1997 MAIN COMMITTEE 3011 of the university. Some of those functions would be there anyway, some would not, with the CRCs and the other relationships. I welcome this legislation and the fact that it is going to pass through the parliament in this session. I welcome the fact that it has had bipartisan support, as it had in the past. I look forward to the continuing successful development of the university under the jurisdiction of the ACT government. It was an anti-Kerr demonstration on the campus of the University of New South Wales. that Sir John Kerr was being unjustly vilified. Anyway, I take the point made by the member for Dickson( Mr Tony Smith) which is obviously right: there is more to life than just money, and there should be more to university life than simply passing exams. I welcome his contribution to this debate on the Education Legislation Amendment Bill 1997. It transfers responsibility for the University of Canberra from the Commonwealth to the ACT government and it also provides to the Australian Maritime College the ability to make by-laws to control its own parking. I should point out that this bill in no way diminishes the Commonwealth's funding obligations to the University of Canberra. The bill has had a rather long march through the legislative process to fruition this evening. It was in April 1993 when the University of Canberra first sought this transfer from Commonwealth to territory jurisdiction, because the university believed that it would be better integrated into the ACT government's education strategies if it came under the ACT's jurisdiction. It believed that, in this way, there would be a closer identification between the university and the ACT. It believed that it would serve the purposes of the university to have as its parliamentary champion, as it were, the ACT minister for education, rather than the federal minister who had many other things on his or her plate. I guess the university thought that it was perhaps better to be a big fish in a small pool, than a small fish in a big pool. Legislation was finally brought into the parliament in late 1995 by the former government, but it lapsed as a result of the election, so this legislation is now before the House. This legislation is a sign of the government's commitment to the ACT. It is a sign of successful lobbying on the part of Professor Aitken, Senator Margaret Reid and many other people. From the government's point of view, placing the University of Canberra under territory jurisdiction puts it in the same position as nearly all other universities, with the exception of the Australian National University. These universities are juridically responsible to state and territory governments, even though the Commonwealth provides the vast preponderance of funds. I am sure the ACT government is appropriately grateful for this chance to exercise stewardship over the University of Canberra while the Commonwealth continues to provide the money. speaker: The Bill, As The Member For Canberra ( Mr Mcmullan) Said, Is A Very Uncontroversial One.
theText: 3012 MAIN COMMITTEE Tuesday, 25 March 1997 Tasmania campus introduced parking restrictions on its students and, as a result, some of those students chose to park in the grounds of the Australian Maritime College. The Australian Maritime College then sought legal advice on its ability to control parking on its own grounds. I am going to read, if I may, some of that advice, because it is important that everyone understands exactly why the government is taking up the parliament's time with this legislation. When the AMC asked the lawyers for advice, it posed this question: Does the College have power to make traffic regulations that are enforceable? The lawyers answered: We note the provisions of Section 24 of the Maritime College Act 1978 which allows the Council to make statutes ... with respect to the ... (a) management, good government and discipline of the College and of the institution conducted by the College. It further allows ... for the imposition, by or on behalf of the College, of penalties upon students of the College or persons employed by the College for contravention of, or failure to comply with, a statute with respect to a matter referred to in paragraph (a). However, the lawyers went on to say: It does not contemplate, by inference, penalties upon "outsiders" such as trespassing students from the University or any other people illegally parked upon College property. The lawyers then advised as follows: If one turns to Section 24(1)(j) which provides that statutes may be enacted for "any other matter necessary or convenient for giving effect to this Act" then one can see that it was obviously the intent of Parliament to provide general powers to the College to govern its own affairs. Its own affairs must, by definition, include the management of its grounds. Nevertheless we are concerned that some legal challenge could, conceivably, be mounted to any parking scheme by reason of the unfortunate wording of Section 24(1)(b) which refers to penalties being imposed only upon students or staff. As a matter of practicality it might be highly unlikely that the scheme would be challenged but nevertheless we feel obliged to point out the possibility. That is what the lawyers said, and that is why this act has come before the parliament. The Australian Maritime College can use an action in trespass against anyone parking improperly on the grounds, but it is always much easier to impose a fine-and hence this legislation. If, as the good Lord says, not a sparrow falls without the knowledge of the Father, I am sure the voters of Australia will be delighted to know that not a car is illicitly parked in the grounds of the AMC in Launceston without the benevolent intervention of the federal government. I commend this important bill to the parliament. Question resolved in the affirmative. Bill read a second time. Message from the Governor General recommending appropriation announced. Bill-by leave-reported to the House without amendment. Consideration resumed from 6 March. Second Reading p.m.)-I move: That the bill be now read a second time.

speaker: Mr Miles (Braddon
theText: Parliamentary Secretary (Cabinet) to the Prime Minister) (6.10Tuesday, 25 March 1997 MAIN COMMITTEE 3013 The Child Support Legislation Amendment Bill (No.1) 1996 contains three changes which were announced by the previous government in the 1995-96 budget as a response to a small number of recommendations made by the Joint Select Committee on Certain Family Law Issues. The bill also includes consequential changes to child support legislation to reflect changes made in the Social Security Act 1991, the Family Law Act 1975 and the Income Tax Assessment Act 1936. The package of measures included in the bill is aimed at increasing flexibility, reducing the level of intrusiveness and improving certainty and clarity in the law. Use of election where income has changed Where a child support liability has been created by an administrative assessment, a parent is able to apply to have the registrar vary the amount of their liability by lodging an income estimate election. An income estimate election often results in a paying parent being entitled to a refund of moneys already paid to the person receiving child support. This causes significant inconvenience for persons receiving child support where the amount of child support has already been spent for the benefit of the children. It also means that the parent paying child support often has to repay most, if not all, of the amount refunded over the remainder of the year at a time when they have less capacity to do so. The bill will amend the effect of an income estimate election to make it less likely that a person receiving child support will be asked to repay amounts in the future and to make the effect of an income estimate election a more accurate reflection of a paying parent's capacity to pay. The revised income estimate will be used to recalculate the amount of the child support properly payable for the year. However, amounts payable prior to the date of lodgement of an estimate will generally be left undisturbed and will be taken into account in arriving at the future liabilities for the remaining period. The only time that amounts payable prior to the lodgement of an estimate will be disturbed is where, after calculating the amount properly payable and the amounts charged to the date of the estimate, the parent has already been charged too much for the year. This will remove a significant and frequent cause for complaint from persons receiving child support. Electing for employer withholding not to apply The bill amends the Child Support (Registration and Collection) Act 1988 to allow a payer of child support to make payments directly to the Child Support Registrar where the registrar is satisfied that a person will make timely payments. This measure will : . reduce the level of intrusiveness of the child support scheme for payers who can be relied upon to make their child support payments directly to the registrar in a timely manner; provide greater flexibility to the registrar in the way he administers the collection of child support and reduce overall administration costs; and reduce the costs of compliance by employers in withholding child support by permitting more payers to pay directly where they can be relied on to make payments in a timely manner. If the registrar refuses to accept an election to pay directly, the payer has the right to object to, and appeal against, this decision. 3014 MAIN COMMITIEE Tuesday, 25 March 1997 The government is conscious that the implications may be severe for children where a payer defaults. The registrar's primary responsibility will continue to be to ensure the collection of child support in a timely manner. In making the proposed change, the government will ensure that there are strict safeguards in the event of default. In the event of default, the registrar will be able to require that child support be withheld from a person's employer in the future and a payer will not be able to make another election until a period of 6 months has elapsed from the date the registrar was required to make arrangements with a person's employer. In most cases, payers who default after choosing to pay directly to the registrar will have strictly limited future access to this provision. Consideration of child support liabilities in property and spousal maintenance proceedings The bill will amend the Family Law Act to enable the court to take into account the child support liability of a person in property and spousal maintenance proceedings, even where a child support assessment has not been issued. Under the existing law, where a person is voluntarily paying child support without an assessment of his child support liability, the amounts paid or to be paid under such arrangements cannot be taken into account by the court in making orders in either property or spousal maintenance proceedings. This may result in courts making orders which do not adequately reflect the true circumstances of the party who is to pay child support. This also means that parties must apply for an assessment even where they wish to make private arrangements regarding child support for the court to take into account these commitments when making orders regarding property or spousal maintenance. This will ensure that separated parents with private arrangements for child support will be treated in the same way as parents who are paying child support under the Child Support (Assessment) Act 1989. Employer record keeping requirements The bill amends the Child Support (Registration and Collection) Act 1988 to reduce the period an employer is required to retain child support records from seven years to five years. This will bring the child support requirement into line with record keeping requirements under the Income Tax Assessment Act 1936. This measure will make it easier for employers to voluntarily comply with their record keeping obligations by having one period for both taxation and child support purposes. It will also result in a slight reduction in the cost of compliance as the period of retention of records for child support purposes has been reduced. Family Law Act 1975 changes The bill brings the child support presumptions of parentage into line with the amended provisions of the Family Law Act 1975. Updating references to the Social Security Act The bill amends the provisions in the Child Support (Assessment) Act 1989 by substituting references to the Social Security Act 1947 with provisions and concepts in the Social Security Act 1991. I commend the bill to the House and present the explanatory memorandum. That all words after "That" be omitted with a view to substituting the following words: "whilst not declining to give the Bill a second reading, the House:

speaker: Mr Latham (Werriwa) (6.17 P.m.)
theText: On behalf of the opposition, I move:Tuesday, 25 March 1997 MAIN COMMITTEE 3015 (1) expresses concern at the failure of the Howard Government, after 12 months in office, to respond to the recommendations of the report of the Joint Select Committee into Certain Family Law Issues entitled 'Child Support Scheme: An Examination of the Operation and Effectiveness of the Scheme'; (2) believes the Government should be concerned about the well-being and welfare of all families: whether they be intact families, separated families, single parent families or serial families; (3) notes with concern the failure to implement some of the report's recommendations has caused parents and their children to suffer needless hardship; (4) believes that there is important and urgent need to improve and strengthen the Child Support Scheme; and (5) considers that much time has been lost and therefore the Government should respond to the recommendations of the report concerned with changing the child support formula as soon as possible and introduce legislation within six months to this effect". I expect that amendment moved by the opposition to be embraced by the government members, particularly their self-appointed experts on the back bench who have stood up on numerous occasions lamenting the shortcomings of the child support scheme. I anticipate the support of the member for Capricornia ( Mr Marek), the member for Bowman( Mrs West), the member for Lindsay (Miss Jackie Kelly), the member for Warringah ( Mr Abbott), the member for Longman( Mr Brough) and the member for Dawson( Mrs De-Anne Kelly)-just to name a few. This has been one of the interesting features of the new government backbench since the last election: their determination to talk big on the question of child support reform but to act very little when it comes to bringing to the parliament substantive amendments. It is, of course, unacceptable that the government after 12 months in office has failed to respond to the findings and recommendations of the parliamentary report of 1994. The measures now before the parliament represent an ALP response from the time of the 1995-96 budget. So, for a government that promised so much and for a government backbench which has spoken so frequently on this matter, one would expect the Howard government to do a lot more than to imitate the Labor proposals that were foreshadowed at the time of the 1995 budget. Once again the Labor Party is in a position where it is here to help the government honour its election commitments to improve the operation, effectiveness and equity of the Child Support Agency. The Child Support Legislation Amendment Bill seeks to introduce certain recommendations of the Joint Select Committee on Certain Family Law Issues, reflecting the changes announced by the former government in August 1995. A major impact of the package is that it streamlines a number of administrative elements of the child support scheme, foreshadowing three changes to existing arrangements: firstly, the use of election where income is changed; secondly, electing for employer withholding not to apply; and, finally, consideration of child support liabilities in family law proceedings. I will deal with the first of these reforms. Parents have the right to apply to the Child Support Registrar to vary the amount of their liability so that either the custodial parent is forced to repay moneys which have already been spent on the supported children in question, or, conversely, that a paying parent is forced to repay most or all of the amount refunded over the remainder of the year. Under the current system, variation to a paying parent's liability has been extremely inconvenient for both the custodial and non-custodial parent. The purpose of this aspect of the amendment is to allow for a more accurate reflection of the payer's future capacity to pay because the amount payable will only be charged for the months remaining after the estimate 3016 MAIN COMMITTEE Tuesday, 25 March 1997 has been lodged. It will also reduce the likelihood of a custodial parent being compelled to make repayments. The second reform is electing for employer withholding not to apply. An amendment to the Child Support (Registration and Collection) Act 1988 will give payers the opportunity to make payments direct to the Child Support Registrar. The only caveat to this is that the registrar be satisfied that the person will make timely payments. The benefits of this change include a saving in administrative costs which would have otherwise been spent in an attempt to make the employers aware of the scheme's operation and their subsequent responsibilities. It also provides a greater choice of method of payment for the non-custodial parent. Many payers opt to make payments directly to the registrar rather than through an employer link, which has the advantages of privacy and confidentiality. Essentially, this change reflects greater discretion in the way the collection of child support is administered. On the final reform, presently any voluntary child support arrangement is not taken into account by the Family Court in either property or spouse maintenance proceedings. The bill will have the effect of putting these arrangements in the same way as a child support assessment and will thus allow the court to more accurately assess the financial circumstances of the parties to the proceedings. As the Parliamentary Secretary (Cabinet) to the Prime Minister( Mr Miles) mentioned, the bill also contains three areas of consequential amendments to related acts. In respect to the Child Support (Registration and Collection) Act 1988, this is an administrative change to bring child support record keeping requirements by employers in line with the Income Tax Assessment Act 1936. The period for which employers must retain child support records will be reduced from seven to five years. The administrative burden on employers in relation to their child support responsibilities will be reduced, and a system of uniform record keeping established between these acts. The Family Law Act 1995 is amended so that the definition of parentage is streamlined by the amendment to bring it in line with the current family law provisions. These incidental amendments cover the definition of a prescribed court, the replacement of parentage in terms of months with a measure of weeks, and the presumptions which arise from cohabitation. The Child Support (Assessment) Act 1989 is being amended to ensure that certain provisions in the act with reference to the Social Security Act 1947 are updated with the provisions of the Social Security Act 1991. One feature of the amendment is that it focuses on the paying parent and examines their rights, rather than solely those of the custodial parent. The rationale is to make it easier for the custodial parent to comply with his or her recognised responsibilities. In relation to the use of election where income has changed, the existing regime has proved to be a real burden for certain types of workers-for example, seasonal workers who are asked to estimate their income for a financial year. At least under this new provision, income estimates provided by such payers will provide a better reflection of their actual capacity to pay. This rationale also applies to consideration of child support liabilities and family law proceedings, allowing for more accurate initial assessment of the financial circumstances of the custodial and non-custodial parent. As members will appreciate, the joint select committee undertook a far-reaching inquiry which began as long ago as 1993 and received a quite impressive total of 6,200 submissions. Tuesday, 25 March 1997 MAIN COMMITTEE 3017 That was the largest number of submissions ever received by any committee of this parliament. In addition, a hotline organised by the committee-the first hotline to operate from Parliament House, Canberra-generated 150,000 calls in two days of operation. In tabling the committee's report, my colleague the member for Chifley, Mr Price, spoke of the need for the Child Support Agency to become a client focused and client sensitive organisation. The report contained over 160 recommendations, which were described as a fine blueprint for reform, designed to chart the way ahead for the child support scheme. Although this was a lengthy process, gradually many of the recommendations in some shape or form have been finding their way into the scheme. This legislation-the Labor response to the select committee-is the final instalment on the recommendations. I believe it is appropriate for the Main Committee and the parliament to acknowledge their appreciation for the work of the joint select committee, particularly the chairperson, Mr Price. It is not an easy area of public policy administration and consideration, but they produced a fine report that has deserved a lot better since the election than the passage of 12 months without any active response to the remaining recommendations by the new federal government. The submissions received by the committee raised several concerns about specific aspects of the child support formula. The areas of the formula which generated the most concern included the non-custodial parent's self-support component, the custodial parent's disregarded income level and the maximum income base against which the child support formula is applied. The joint committee report was an important analysis of a very complex government program. The opposition's call, through the amendment I moved earlier, for legislation to amend the child support assessment formula within the next six months follows considerable debate on this complex issue. No member could doubt the significance of the bill before us, but it is disappointing indeed, for the opposition and for tens of thousands of families subject to the child support scheme, that some of the recommendations in the report have still not been addressed at this stage. As the Department of Social Security pointed out in its submission to the child support inquiry: There are no absolutes in relation to child support. Rather the issue is the balance points between separated and intact families; between children of first and subsequent families; between custodial and non-custodial parents; and between parents and taxpayers generally. These balance points are complex and, in both social and economic terms, are affected by the interactions of the taxation, social security and child support systems. The Inquiry provides the opportunity to re-test the balance points and to clear the air on certain issues which have emerged. With many other members of parliament, I have encountered numerous cases of the. 'balance points' the department refers to, through the work that I have undertaken with constituents in my electorate office. I appreciate that any changes to the formula will change the balance between the interests of custodial and non-custodial parents and taxpayers. There are very few instances, particularly when it comes to consideration of the formula, where policy makers can examine win-win scenarios. This is an area of policy, in the absence of major injections of public funding, where most of the reforms throw up the prospect of win-lose scenarios. So the application of sound policy principles is all important. I can foreshadow that, as the opposition member now chartered with some shadow responsibilities for child support, I will be trying to apply some fresh principles to this complex area of public policy. 3018 MAIN COMMITTEE Tuesday, 25 March 1997 As is so often the case with these win-lose scenarios, the child support area has been seen through the prism of gender equity issues. I am disappointed that so many of these debates seem to have fallen to the level of pitching male versus female interests. It is much healthier for the parliament and parliamentarians to consider child support through the prism of income equity concerns and to examine the fairness of the existing income transfers implicit in the formula. We should blindfold ourselves to whether the parent is male or female, and rather take an income equity focus on these questions. I look forward-although I know some members would not do so-to playing an active role in the child support area. It is complex. There are no easy answers. But I believe that by applying some fresh principles of social justice and income equity to these questions, and by blindfolding ourselves to the gender equity concerns, the parliament can have a far healthier and productive debate than we have had to this point in time. There is no doubt that changes to the formula are contentious. But my assessment is that the joint select committee report raised all the issues in a very fair fashion and came up with workable recommendations in that respect. In my own electorate of Werriwa there are approximately 6,000 registered non-custodial parents who are paying child support for their children. From my discussions and correspondence with many of these parents, I can assure the Main Committee that they are waiting anxiously for the promised reform of the Child Support Agency to become law and, indeed, administrative practice. It is now commonly accepted that change is needed to the child support scheme. The real issue is the degree of change. I say to honourable members that we cannot afford to be complacent about the recommendations of the joint committee in this regard. The package of some 160 recommendations aims to strengthen the scheme, not weaken it. At the last federal election, the coalition's policy was meant to outline their position in relation to child support matters. However, apart from identifying the joint committee's report, the six-page document released by the coalition had very little to offer. The reason I am moving the amendment standing in my name, and the reason the opposition is confident that government members, if they match their rhetoric, will h\lve no problem with it, is found in the coalition's Child Support Agency election platform. On the front page of the policy the coalition described the findings of the joint committee as: ... a solid basis for ongoing reform of the Agency. If that is the case, if the recommendations are such a solid basis for ongoing reform of the agency, why hasn't the government responded to them 12 months after the last election? Their policy document went on to say: The coalition will fully address the concerns of the Joint Select Committee on Certain Family Law Issues. After the passage of one year, any reasonable person would have to conclude that that could not have been a core promise. It must have been a non-core promise because the government has not addressed any of the concems of the Joint Select Committee on Certain Family Law issues. It has ducked for cover. It has failed to fulfil the high expectations it set in so many electorates-particularly those along the coastal strip of Queensland and especially in the mining towns-that it would act on the findings of the joint committee. It is regrettable that the government has been so tardy in this particular process. Tuesday, 25 March 1997 MAIN COMMITTEE 3019 I also take up the words of the member for Berowra( Mr Ruddock), who was then the shadow minister for social security. Before the last election, in a media release issued on 22 February 1996, he stated: A Coalition Government will reform the Child Support Agency and the Child Support Scheme. He stated that the priorities for the coalition in office would be to ensure that the child support formula was made equitable to, as he said: ... offer a better deal for custodial and non-custodial parents alike. I make the point again: after the passage of 12 months in office, the new government has not made any change, or proposed any changes, to the child support formula. That statement was made some 13 months ago and not a single change has yet been introduced by this government. So there has been not only a failure to match the high expectations before the election, but also a failure to match up to the rhetoric since the election. You only had to tum on the radio through the New Year-January period to know that the member for Herbert( Mr Lindsay) in particular was boasting on the airwaves about the sort of support and momentum he was supposedly generating within the government for major changes to the child support formula. Whatever happened to that big talk? Whatever happened to that momentum? He produced a survey and was quoted in the West Australian newspaper on 2 January this year as saying that he had assessed the views of 60 coalition backbenchers and that 95 per cent of them wanted the Child Support Agency laws and formula changed. The opposition's second reading amendment calls for change. After more than 12 months, it is time to transform the necessary changes and the high rhetoric of people such as the member for Herbert into the law of the Commonwealth. I look forward to the support of the 60 coalition backbenchers who say they want change and to them actually voting for change by supporting the opposition amendment. In these matters I suppose the government might be reaching for excuses. One of them might be that its chosen minister, initially, for looking after the child support area was Senator Short. He hit the wall on other matters-not child support but financial support for himself, and his declaration of it to the parliament. I sent him many pieces of correspondence from my electorate, from people concerned about the administration of child support, but among the scores of letters that I had sent on to his office by the time of his fall I received only one back. It is worth quoting. It is the Jim Short memorial letter on child support matters, which he might care to take with him on his way to an overseas job for the boy. It says: Since becoming responsible for child support administration, many of you have told me of the need to improve the Child Support Agency's operations. Many electorate offices deal regularly with client complaints on issues which we expect could have been resolved by a simple phone call to the CSA. I am keen to address the problems that many clients are facing with the CSA and, through this, to reducing the number of CSA complaints which are being handled by staff in electorate offices and by Members and Senators themselves. The Coalition Government's policy on child support commits us to administrative reform of the CSA and to addressing the concerns of the Joint Select Committee on Certain Family Law Issues. Senator Short did not deliver. All he could promise, effectively, was the resolution of these matters by a phone call-as he put it, a simple phone call. It takes more than that. It takes a bill, draft legislation, consideration by the parliament and acting on the findings of the joint committee report. 3020 MAIN COMMITTEE Tuesday, 25 March 1997 Unfortunately, Jim Short's fascination with shares and pecuniary interests meant that he was not around long enough to put his rhetoric into action. The belief of the previous minister that the child support complaints brought to the attention of electorate offices can be resolved by 'one simple phone call' illustrates the severe short-sightedness of this government. I do not know of any aggrieved client of the Child Support Agency who believes their problems can be resolved by a phone call alone. Indeed, the joint committee's report highlighted the inadequacies of the communication channels that exist between staff and clients. After more than 12 months in office this government has failed to take any steps to honour its election commitment to implement the recommendations of the joint select committee's report. This is the opportunity for those government backbenchers who have been vocal in bringing to the attention of the House specific cases of the system's failings to do more than just talk about it. Let me quote from some of the rhetoric that we have heard in recent times. I know I am supported in the amendment that I have moved by the member for Capricornia, or at least supported in his media release of 12 September 1996, which reads: After the meetingwith the Lone Fathers Association, in the town of RockhamptonMr Marek said he is keen to see the issues raised by the Lone Fathers' Association addressed by the Government as quickly as possible and will continue to make representations in the matter until they are properly resolved. That was some six to seven months ago and still there is no action. Item (5) of the opposition's amendment today is very kind to the member for Capricornia and his colleagues. We are giving him and the government six more months in which to legislate on changes to the child support formula. It is in their hands and, indeed, the hands of the entire coalition backbench to vote for our amendment and bind the government to change the law. Having discussed some specific areas of reform, I want to mention the need to strengthen the CSA's administration, to allow it to better serve its clients through effective communication. These communication problems spark the need for a child support clients charter to improve service delivery. This was an initiative of the previous Labor government. In January 1996 George Gear, as Assistant Treasurer, introduced the charter designed to improve the working relationship between clients and the CSA by setting out in plain English what parents can expect and their responsibilities in ensuring a future for the children. Specifically, the charter identifies the responsibility of those CSA clients and staff on issues such as codes of conduct, service standards, compensation, and a dispute resolution and review mechanism. The charter complemented an earlier $50 million boost to CSA resources, targeted at all agency offices in an attempt to allocate more staff to phones and upgraded communications technology within the agency. Better communications require complementary resources, especially staff. Documents obtained by the federal opposition showed, in October last year, that the government is actually closing suburban Sydney CSA offices, abandoning thousands of clients outside the Sydney CBD. The hardest hit areas will be west and south-west Sydney, where the Penrith, Bankstown and Hurstville offices will in the next few years be closed, losing somewhere in the vicinity of 250 jobs. The Bankstown office caters for my electorate, as it would, I expect, for the electorate of the member of Fowler( Mr Ted Grace), and I shudder to think that in a few years time constituents from Campbelltown and Liverpool will be forced to travel to the city if they need to see a CSA review officer. This will be over an hour of travel by public transport each way. Tuesday, 25 March 1997 MAIN COMMITTEE 3021 Following its extensive inquiry, the joint committee came to the conclusion that the current self-support component which applies to the non-custodial parent with no subsequent family, equivalent to the single pension rate, is set at too Iowa level. By quoting the self-support components of the single pension rate, the child support formula fails to truly reflect the additional costs of employment which are carried out by employed non-custodial parents and the additional fringe benefits available to pensioners. Accordingly, recommendation 123 of the joint committee report suggests that the self-support component, referred to as the excluded income amount in the amendments, be increased. It argued that such a change would go a long way to achieving the best resolution of the balance points referred to earlier. The parents I speak to commonly cite the frustration which is felt with regard to the self-support component of the formula. The sooner we act on this frustration the better. I receive scores of letters from frustrated parents from all over the country who are disillusioned with the government's and, in particular, with the Assistant Treasurer's unwillingness to act on their concern after all the election promises for reform. The only public comments that have been attributed to ministers was a matter that appeared in the Courier-Mail on 13 February this year. It said: Social Security Minister Jocelyn Newman and Assistant Treasurer Rod Kemp are understood to be examining initial proposals but are concerned at possible budgetary effects. This confirms again that the government is treating child support as a non-core promise. We all know that if the government is shying away because of possible budgetary effects, because of their slash and bum approach to fiscal policy, those citizens right around Australia concerned about the workings of the Child Support Agency should not hold their breath expecting this government to produce positive legislative changes to the formula. Labor's second reading amendment has the potential to make a difference to the lives of almost a million Australians who are affected by the child support scheme. The agency's caseload has grown from just 58 cases in 1988 to cover 360,000 cases today, the equivalent of 720,000 clients. It is projected that this caseload will increase by an average of 5,000 cases a month. In addition to this workload, the CSA receives an estimated 11,000 telephone calls and in excess of 4,000 letters a day. These are staggering figures by any account and the problems that have arisen largely because of the CSA's rate of growth have exceeded all expectations. That confirms beyond all doubt that this is, if I can use the term, a mainstream issue and concern to the Australian people. It is not something that should necessarily be sent away to the Main Committee alone. I look forward to the House voting on my second reading amendment. With that level of caseload, with 720,000 clients and growing by 5,000 cases a month, this is an issue that every single member of this parliament must address. Every single member must be urging the minister responsible, Senator Kemp, to act on the findings of the joint committee and to bring a much fairer system of child support to all those citizens around Australia who rely on this parliament for a much fairer deal. Mr Ted Grace-I second the amendment. Debate (on motion by Mr Miles) adjourned. Main Committee adjourned at 6.45 p.m.
